image.altText: Picture of a sign saying caution with an open pit coal mine and power station in the background

items.synopsis: A supposed exemplar of energy security and prescience just last year, Western Australia is now facing calls for a shake-up of its policies amid soaring prices and supply strains.

title.children: Australia's energy woes shift west as state's power and gas prices head skywards

image.altText: A man is lowered into a mine shaft

items.synopsis: Pictures document a painstaking search for clues in WA's remote Mid-West region, as police return to the century-old mineshaft where the body of an amateur prospector was found eight years ago.

title.children: Police dig up mine shaft in hope of solving baffling WA outback murder mystery

image.altText: portrait shot of Andrea in front of tiles in kitchen

items.synopsis: Andrea was five when she discovered she was adopted and she's struggled with the fallout for decades. It's why she's determined to see a trauma support service created for forced adoption survivors.

title.children: 'I would just go in a spiral': Why Andrea can't celebrate her birthday and has vowed she never will

image.altText: Kiwi crossing in New Zealand

items.synopsis: New Zealand was among the first developed economies to start increasing interest rates, and it is yet to see inflation in its target zone. This is how the country compares to Australia.

title.children: New Zealand is officially in a recession. These charts show how Australia compares

image.altText: Liberal Senator David Van

items.synopsis: Former Queensland Liberal senator Amanda Stoker accuses senator David Van of inappropriately touching her at a social gathering in 2020, but he says it's not something he'd ever do.

title.children: Former Liberal senator accuses David Van of 'inappropriate touching', which Van denies

image.altText: A crowd of people in a auditorium.

items.synopsis: WA's Aboriginal Affairs Minister says concerns raised by farmers and landholders about the state's post-Juukan Gorge heritage reforms are misplaced.

title.children: WA government stands firm on Aboriginal heritage reforms despite growing calls for delay

image.altText: LIz Indrans

items.synopsis: A report by Swinburne University of Technology found 10 companies that trialled a four-day work week continued it after a pilot, with four organisations adopting the change permanently.

title.children: These employers have introduced four-day work weeks and 'can't think of a downside'

image.altText: Indigenous woman Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks to a forum, with and Indegenous elder and child flanked either side.

items.synopsis: With a referendum on the Voice to Parliament approaching in the second half of the year, there's one myth about the proposed body which refuses to die, despite repeated debunking.

title.children: This myth about the Voice pushed by No campaigners including Jacinta Nampijinpa Price refuses to die

image.altText: Screenshot from a video showing a police car and people holding up a tarp by the road

items.synopsis: Video from the scene showed firefighters spraying water on a burning white vehicle that was in a ditch to the side of the road.

title.children: At least 15 people dead in Canada as truck hits bus carrying elderly people

image.altText: Ice in the ocean

items.synopsis: This year has already produced record high ocean temperatures, record low Antarctic sea ice, and global air temperatures well above average all year.

title.children: Sudden surge of record high temperatures could propel 2023 as warmest year on record

image.altText: A close-up of Prime Minister Boris Johnson during a televised address.

items.synopsis: Throughout the partygate scandal, Boris Johnson maintained "hand on heart" he believed the lockdown parties were lawful. Here's why a parliamentary committee didn't believe him.

title.children: How Boris Johnson became the first prime minister to deliberately mislead the UK parliament

image.altText: Man wearing a black top with red stripe, standing outside.

items.synopsis: Amid a shift away from opioids — with prescriptions dropping 30 per cent between 2016 and 2021 — chronic pain sufferers like Daniel King are experiencing acute distress.

title.children: 'It's soul destroying': A shift away from opioid prescriptions is causing distress for people with chronic pain

image.altText: A picture of the outside of a business in an industrial area

items.synopsis: A teenage boy dies from his injuries after an incident on Thursday morning at the factory where he worked in Perth's south-east.

title.children: 'Youngest fatality': Teenager's death at industrial business is latest in spate of WA workplace deaths

image.altText: Bunch of flowers with a note a attached.

items.synopsis: A fundraiser to help those affected by the fatal bus crash in the NSW Hunter Valley raises an astonishing amount of money, as hundreds gather for a community vigil at the crash site.

title.children: More than $240k donated to Hunter Valley wedding bus crash victims and their families

image.altText: A mug shot of a man

items.synopsis: He's already serving three life sentences after confessing to a trio of underworld murders. Now Abuzar Sultani has been sentenced for his role in the death of a teenager in Sydney 10 years ago.

title.children: 'Serial killer': Sydney underworld hit man sentenced after pleading guilty to fourth murder

image.altText: Woman staring through window with reflection of sky.

items.synopsis: A weather blackout zone in the heart of the country means graziers don't know what the sky will do, and the Bureau of Meteorology can't tell them.

title.children: Weather apps are a farmer's best friend, but in this outback town they're useless

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it is pushing Russian forces back in places along the southern and eastern frontlines, while Moscow announces plans for elections in occupied areas in its latest bid to signal it is in control.

title.children: Bodycam vision shows intense gunfights as Ukraine pushes on with counteroffensive

image.altText: Joko Widodo sitting in front of a microphone

items.synopsis: Treasury staff must register all gifts received. Those over $100 go on the internet. Those below that value have been uncovered in FOI documents obtained by the ABC.

title.children: Treasury gets the chocolates as gift registry exposed

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: Local shares are expected to open higher today, after Wall Street rose. ECB lifts rates. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to rise, Wall Street rallies, Europe lifts rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It was a strong day on Wall Street overnight, as investors continued to react to the Federal Reserve's rate pause. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 428.73 points, or 1.26%, to 34,408.06, the S & P 500 gained 53.25 points, or 1.22%, to 4,425.84 and the Nasdaq Composite added 156.34 points, or 1.15%, to 13,782.82. In tech, shares of Microsoft and Oracle were higher with gains of about 3.2% and 3.5%. Alibaba stock climbed close to 3.2%. US jobless claims were higher than expected, while sales unexpectedly rose in May as consumers stepped up purchases of motor vehicles and building materials, which could help to stave off a recession in the near term. The higher jobless claims helped fuel bets that the Fed would not follow through with more rate hikes. This, combined with higher-than-expected retail sales, looked like "the ingredients for a soft landing" for the US said Irene Tunkel, chief US equity strategist at BCA Research. "It's almost like a sweet spot," Ms Tunkel said, also pointing to Chinese data boosting energy stocks and oil prices. "So, sentiment-wise the mood is positive." In Europe, the euro hit a 15-year peak against the Japanese yen and a five-week high against the dollar after the European Central Bank lifted interest rates to a two-decade high of 3.5% and eyed more hikes ahead. Equities trading had been choppy on Wednesday after the Fed signalled it could follow its June pause with two more rate increases this year. But on Thursday afternoon the S & P 500 and Nasdaq were rallying sharply and registered their highest closing levels in roughly 14 months. But the dollar index, measuring the greenback against major currencies, fell 0.787%, with the euro up 1.06% to $1.0946 after earlier hitting a high of $1.09520. The Japanese yen weakened 0.11% versus the greenback at 140.24 per dollar, while Sterling was last trading at $1.2782, up 0.96% on the day. "Beyond the near-term outlook for rates, the U.S. dollar may be looking at a somewhat more challenging environment. The global monetary policy cycle is approaching its end game," said Shaun Osborne, chief FX strategist, said at Scotiabank. Mr Osborne added that the rate-cycle peak would be negative for the dollar as it would boost appetites for riskier bets. US Treasury yields were lower as investors digested the economic data and the Fed's update. Benchmark 10-year notes were down 8 basis points to 3.718%, from 3.798% late on Wednesday. The 30-year bond was last down 3.9 basis points to yield 3.8421% while the 2-year note was last was down 6.5 basis points to yield 4.6418%. - with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gains on Wall Street

children.content: It was a strong day on Wall Street overnight, as investors continued to react to the Federal Reserve's rate pause.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average
rose 428.73 points, or 1.26%, to 34,408.06, the S
P 500 gained 53.25 points, or 1.22%, to 4,425.84 and the Nasdaq Composite added 156.34 points, or 1.15%, to 13,782.82.
In tech, shares of Microsoft and Oracle were higher with gains of about 3.2% and 3.5%. Alibaba stock climbed close to 3.2%.
US jobless claims were higher than expected, while sales
unexpectedly rose in May as consumers stepped up purchases of motor vehicles and building materials, which could help to stave off a recession in the near term.
The higher jobless claims helped fuel bets that the Fed would not follow through with more rate hikes.
This, combined with higher-than-expected retail sales, looked like "the ingredients for a soft landing" for the US said Irene Tunkel, chief US equity strategist at BCA Research.
"It's almost like a sweet spot," Ms Tunkel said, also pointing to Chinese data boosting energy stocks and oil prices. "So, sentiment-wise the mood is positive."
In Europe, the euro hit a 15-year peak against the Japanese yen and a five-week high against the dollar after the European Central Bank lifted
interest rates to a two-decade high of 3.5% and eyed more hikes ahead.
Equities trading had been choppy on Wednesday after the Fed signalled
it could follow its June pause with two more rate increases this year. But on Thursday afternoon the S
P 500 and Nasdaq
were rallying sharply and registered their highest closing levels in roughly 14 months.
But the dollar index, measuring the greenback against major currencies, fell 0.787%, with the euro
up 1.06% to $1.0946 after earlier hitting a high of $1.09520.
The Japanese yen weakened 0.11% versus the greenback at 140.24 per dollar, while Sterling was last trading at $1.2782, up 0.96% on the day.

"Beyond the near-term outlook for rates, the U.S. dollar may be looking at a somewhat more challenging environment. The global monetary policy cycle is approaching its end game," said Shaun Osborne, chief FX strategist, said at Scotiabank.
Mr Osborne added that the rate-cycle peak would be negative for the dollar as it would boost appetites for riskier bets.
US Treasury yields
were lower as investors digested the economic data and the Fed's update.

Benchmark 10-year notes were down 8 basis points to 3.718%, from 3.798% late on Wednesday. The 30-year bond was last down 3.9 basis points to yield 3.8421% while the 2-year note was last was down 6.5 basis points to yield 4.6418%.
- with Reuters

image.altText: Argentina's Lionel Messi shoots the ball at the goal.

items.synopsis: The irrepressible Lionel Messi again brings the Socceroos' undone, scoring the fastest goal of his international career as Argentina claims a friendly victory in Beijing.

image.altText: Close-up of rifle trigger.

items.synopsis: A gunman charged with shooting at a car with two people and their infant inside allegedly told the driver of the vehicle, the next time "I won't f***ing miss you".

title.children: Canberra man who allegedy used a rifle to shoot at car with baby inside told driver he 'wouldn't miss' next time

image.altText: Close-up photo of baby feet laying on a white blanket.

items.synopsis: Shocking images of a 10-week-old baby covered in scratches inflicted by another child at a Melbourne childcare centre have sparked cause for concern among parents this week. So, what can parents do to prevent injuries at childcare?

title.children: Images of a baby's scratched face shocked parents. So what can be done to prevent childcare injuries?

image.altText: Glenda Jackson on a red carpet.

items.synopsis: Glenda Jackson, a two-time Academy Award-winning performer who had a second career in politics as a British MP, dies aged 87.

image.altText: Lachie Dent and Chantelle Bongers smiling in a selfie taken at a bar next to bright blue water.

items.synopsis: Amid rising inflation and interest rates and stubbornly high prices for flights, the number of Australian residents travelling overseas has yet to return to pre-pandemic levels. But some countries are getting more Australian visitors than others.

title.children: Fiji wasn't Lachie and Chantelle's first choice of holiday destination. But the cheaper option turned out to be the best

image.altText: Two Aboriginal girls in school uniforms look at models made of plasticine

items.synopsis: Students from the remote Northern Territory homeland of Nganambala are using space-inspired technology to design infrastructure for their community.

title.children: In this remote community, there is no phone reception. These kids are working to change that

image.altText: A man smiles.

items.synopsis: The yachtsman, winemaker and businessman — who was part of the team that wrested the America's Cup from the United States — dies in Adelaide aged 90.

title.children: Champion yachtsman and wine boss Sir James Hardy dies aged 90

items.synopsis: Dial of Destiny is the fifth and final instalment in the Indiana Jones franchise, which started with 1981’s Raiders of the Lost Ark.

title.children: 'He's as mad as a box of squirrels': Behind the scenes of the final Indiana Jones adventure

image.altText: Person with long, light-coloured hair smiling wearing a dark jumper.

items.synopsis: Being a gender-diverse person on the sporting field can come with challenges. For Alex and Roxie, the reaction from their local football community has been mixed.

title.children: After 10 years as a referee, Alex came out as transgender. She was met with mixed reactions on the football field

items.synopsis: It was a Sunday afternoon in Port Arthur in 1996 when the three people Walter Mikac loved most were brutally taken from him.

title.children: Nine days after Walter lost his entire family, he sent a letter that helped change the course of Australian history
